description: From Anglo-Norman repeler, from Old French rapeler (“to call back, call in, call after, revoke”), from Latin repellō (“drive or thrust back”), from re- and pellō (“push or strike”).  Doublet of repel.

entries.meaning: An act or instance of repealing.
examples: When a newer Act of Parliament is incompatible with earlier law, it usually takes precedence, under the doctrine of “implied repeal”.

verbs.description: repeal (third-person singular simple present repeals, present participle repealing, simple past and past participle repealed)

entries.meaning: To recall; to summon (a person) again; to bring (a person) back from exile or banishment.
